awd_titl_txt: CRII: CPS: Towards Optimal Information Gathering in Unknown Stochastic Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Society is steadily moving toward a world in which autonomous vehicles roam the streets side-by-side with human-driven vehicles and unmanned aerial vehicles are integrated into the national airspace. These autonomous systems will be tasked with missions such as search, rescue, surveillance, reconnaissance, mapping, farming, fire fighting, and transportation. Future autonomous systems will operate in unfamiliar areas with minimal or no human interaction for prolonged periods of time. The luxury of building prior detailed maps of these environments could be (1) prohibitive (e.g., disaster areas), (2) impractical (e.g., signal landscapes and congested downtowns), or (3) economically not viable (e.g., hospital buildings and national forests). With no human-in-the-loop before or during operation, one expects future autonomous systems to (1) possess full situational awareness and (2) gather sufficient information about their environment. These two tasks need to seamlessly integrate into the overall mission of the autonomous system. Current autonomous systems are far from possessing these capabilities, and the current analytical tools are insufficient to deal with this emerging class of problems.

This project will develop a coherent analytical foundation and a suite of algorithms and tools for autonomous systems deployed in unknown, dynamic stochastic environments to optimally gather sufficient information to successfully accomplish their mission. The research specifically considers autonomous systems with limited sensing, computation, actuation, and communication capabilities. This research will study a new class of information optimization measures, which possess desirable convexity properties (enabling real-time execution) and separability properties (enabling near-lossless distributed implementation among agents). This research aims to establish fundamental relationships between performance and computational complexity in the presence of varying degrees of environmental uncertainty. These relationships will enable principled navigation of these complex trade-offs, leading to autonomous identification and adoption of the optimal information gathering strategy. 

This project has a vertically-integrated education plan spanning K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students. The project will also train in-service and pre-service K-12 teachers to apply Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) - a set of science standards that integrate rigorous content and application, reflecting how STEM is practiced in the real world. This research has far-reaching impact - it will evolve autonomous systems from sensing the environment to making sense of the environment, bringing new capabilities in environments where direct human control is physically or economically not possible.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Society is steadily moving toward a world in which autonomous vehicles roam the streets side-by-side with human-driven vehicles and unmanned aerial vehicles are integrated into the national airspace. These autonomous systems will be tasked with missions such as search, rescue, surveillance, reconnaissance, mapping, farming, firefighting, and transportation. Future autonomous systems will operate in unfamiliar areas with minimal or no human interaction for prolonged periods of time. The luxury of building prior detailed maps of these environments could be (1) prohibitive (e.g., disaster areas), (2) impractical (e.g., signal landscapes and congested downtowns), or (3) economically not viable (e.g., hospital buildings and national forests). With no human-in-the-loop before or during operation, one expects future autonomous systems to (1) possess full situational awareness and (2) gather sufficient information about their environment. These two tasks need to seamlessly integrate into the overall mission of the autonomous system. Current autonomous systems are far from possessing these capabilities, and the current analytical tools are insufficient to deal with this emerging class of problems.

This project developed a coherent analytical foundation and a suite of algorithms and tools for autonomous systems deployed in unknown, dynamic stochastic environments to optimally gather sufficient information to successfully accomplish their mission. The research specifically considered autonomous systems with limited sensing, computation, actuation, and communication capabilities. The project developed theory, algorithms, and experimental prototypes for 3 different classes of autonomous vehicles: unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), self-driving cars, and maritime autonomous surface vehicles. For these systems, the project developed algorithms enabling the vehicles to: (1) select the appropriate source of information from its environment (e.g., signal received from a terrestrial source or a satellite, onboard sensor measurements, and data communicated by another autonomous agent in its environment), (2) fuse the information in a computationally and cost efficient fashion, and (3) prescribe optimal trajectories to follow within the environment, while guaranteeing safe and efficient operation. The intellectual products from this project resulted in 21 peer-reviewed journal and conference papers, 2 M.S. Theses and 2 Ph.D. Dissertations, and appeared on the April 2017 cover of GPS World Magazine in the article "LTE Steers UAV."

The project developed a vertically-integrated education plan spanning K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students. It engaged 3 postdocs, 5 Ph.D. students, 4 M.S. students, 12 undergraduate students, and 2 high school students. One of the Ph.D. students funded through this project received the prestigious 2021 IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Society (AESS) Robert T. Hill Best Dissertation for his Ph.D. Dissertation titled "Precise navigation with cellular signals: Receiver design, differential and non-differential frameworks, and performance analysis;" while another Ph.D. student funded through this project received the prestigious 2017 US Department of Transportation (USDOT) Graduate Student of the Year award. This annual award honors the most outstanding graduate students for their achievements and promise for future contributions to the transportation field.

The project developed and hosted a "Game of Drones," an annual competition for middle and high school students to inspire students to pursue science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. Each annual episode of Game of Drones involved about 40-60 students. These games span nearly a full day of fun and engaging games involving drones to inspire students to pursue STEM fields and show the students how STEM is applied in the real world. Other activities throughout the day include showcasing why STEM "is cooler than you think," tour of the campus, and lunch. The winning team was awarded a prize and all participants were given a souvenir to commemorate the day.

This project has far-reaching impact - it helped evolve autonomous systems from sensing the environment to making sense of the environment, bringing new capabilities in environments where direct human control is physically or economically not possible.

 


Last Modified: 09/16/2022
Modified by: Zak M Kassas
